title: Guardian climate score: how did your MP do?
text:
Parliament declared a climate emergency in May, but what do MPs’ voting records indicate about their commitment to the issue?

The Guardian’s climate ranking shows readers their MP’s record on 16 indicative climate votes between 2008 and 2018. Each MP has been assigned a score between 0% and 100% based on their voting record, represented as a dot on the graphic below.

The lower the score, the worse the record. Where multiple MPs have the same score, the dots are clustered together.

The scores are accompanied, if applicable, by their declared interests related to fossil fuel companies, climate sceptics and airports.

This analysis is meant to be a starting point, rather than the final word. Due to the party whip system and arcane parliamentary rules, it cannot be a definitive guide to an MP’s climate credentials. But it is a tool for voters to question whether their MPs are representing their climate concerns.

The votes and a list of relevant interests were chosen by the Guardian and DeSmog, in consultation with other experts, who also determined whether votes were pro-climate or not. Full methodology here.

Despite parliament’s support for ever greater long-term emissions-cutting goals, politicians have consistently shot down practical short-term measures. There have been occasional rebellions against the party whip – most dramatically during the 2018 Heathrow expansion vote. But nothing on the scale of Brexit, suggesting most MPs consider the climate a lesser priority.

Note on methodology

Analysis: The approach used has certain limitations. Earlier this year parliament endorsed the Conservative administration’s proposal to make the UK carbon neutral by 2050 and also approved a Labour party motion to declare a climate emergency. However, because these votes were passed by general assent, no voting record is available for either and they could not be incorporated into the scores.

Votes: The 16 votes chosen for the analysis took place between 28 October 2008 (the third reading of the climate change bill) and 3 July 2019 (Heathrow north-west runway). MPs must have voted at least three times to receive a score.

Graphic: When multiple MPs have the same score their respective dots stack up vertically on the graph. In cases where the number of MPs with the same score do not fit in the space available, an algorithm has rearranged them in clusters. The precise score can be seen by clicking on a dot, hovering the cursor over it, or searching for the MP’s scorecard in the search box.

Party affiliation: MPs are listed as belonging to the party they are affiliated with at the time of publication.

Full methodology here.
description: Use our interactive tool to explore MPs’ records on 16 climate votes
